You are the viking, a hero who probably wouldn't look out of place in Final Fantasy 4's Dwarven Kingdom. I mean, just look at that magnificent beard. Anyway, you've been summoned by Odin to rid Asgard of Loki's minions. The story is a standard Norse tale, but the final boss being determined by choices made at pivotal moments in the plot is a nice touch. Oh what am I saying? Not even one paragraph into the review and I'm already talking about the end. So let's step back for just a minute.

Your progress in Trial by Viking is determined not just by being able to reach the end of the 100+ levels. You also have to find sun-crystals. These shiny gems are used to purchase abilities, tools, and weapon-upgrades. This is one of the interesting aspects of this game. Eventually you'll need certain items in order to progress, but there's nothing stopping you from getting them early, in order to make certain levels easier. However, you also have to be considerate of the fact that there are only so many crystals in each level. You can't expect to repeat levels in order to farm them.

Before I start discussing the controls, I want to briefly touch on Super Metroid. As fantastic as this game is, its controls could be considered floaty" by some people. The jump physics

reviewText: This is one of my favorite indie platformers. It starts off relatively easy and then becomes gruesomely difficult over the course of 130 hand-crafted levels. You run around collecting Sunstones which can be used to purchase better stuff - magic axes, a grappling hook, double jump, etc - which you'll need to take down tougher challenges. Levels can be repeated to collect Sunstones or bonuses you may have missed, or just to get a better time (the game is speedrun-friendly). There's a lot of level variety: bosses/minibosses every 5 levels, mobility challenges, puzzles, lots of new mechanics being introduced throughout the game, hidden areas, etc. Impressively, the whole thing was put together by pretty much one guy.\n\nI Kickstarted this a while back and I've logged over 60 hours as I write this; I can easily see myself logging 60 more as I try to beat it again on the highest difficulty setting and chase those last few achievements.

reviewText: My first look and review of Trial by Viking:\n\nhttps://youtu.be/dgbVs6Jy964

Yes, it does take some time to get a hang of the controls, but once you get the timing down combat becomes a lot easier, making speed runs possible! The game feels balanced, using the gems to customize your equipment adds a great dynamic to the game. I've had to play a level multiple times before I figured out the proper weapons and sub-items to bring. I never feel that the levels are over/under balanced because of the items available.
Puzzles, the game is full of them, and they more and more challenging as the game progresses. Holding UP on the d-pad to zoom out is the best way to plan out your attack, an extremely valuable tool. I've meticulously completed the first 35 levels with 100% completion, that's just how I play. I'm looking forward to unlocking all the items and seeing how difficult the later puzzles can get!
Cons: Resetting the items takes some patience when re-equipping/buying. It's easy to get button mash happy and accidently jump right into the next level. Also the story, though entertaining, doesn't grip me. I'm more eager to jump into the world and explore. The good news is that you'll get a cut scene about every 5 levels or so, making it predictable and  easy to fast forward if you've already read the dialogue.

Overall I recommend this game, it brings a nostalgia from the SNES games I grew up with and loved. And the level design is sneaky, intelligent, and well thought out, it keeps me wanting more!
